prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: In addition to motions for initial transfer, a party may seek to add a later-filed action to the multidistrict cases or may learn of another previously pending case which should be part of the multidistrict group. Such cases are known as “tag-along” actions, and a case may be given “tag-along” status by filing a motion for it. Whenever a case comes to the attention of the Clerk of the Panel (this usually occurs by motion of a party), he or she is authorized to enter a conditional transfer order transferring the action to a court where previously transferred cases are pending. The Panel Rules require any party to transferred multidistrict litigation to advise the Clerk of any additional related case to which that party is a party.[1]

The conditional order is served on all parties, but transfer does not occur for 7 days in order to give the parties an opportunity to object to transfer.[2] A motion to have an action transferred as a tag-along action is subject to the rules of the Panel pertaining to all motions, although the strong presumption in favor of transferring and consolidating makes the burden of briefing the motion less onerous.[3] If tag-along treatment is opposed, the opposing party must file a Notice of Opposition within 7 days after the Clerk of the Panel enters the conditional transfer order, and must then file a motion to vacate the conditional transfer order within 14 days after entry of the conditional transfer order.

A conditional transfer order is entered automatically by the Clerk of the Panel whenever he or she learns of a case apparently sharing common facts with actions previously transferred by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. A conditional transfer order becomes effective if not objected to, but has no significant vitality if there is an objection. It does not reflect a presumption that transfer is appropriate or a prejudgment of objections to transfer. The Panel has stated:

[T]he “Conditional Transfer Order” is an administrative device used to expeditiously transfer apparently related cases where there is no opposition to such a transfer. It should not be considered by counsel as a decision or judgment by the Panel which must be reversed before such an order can be vacated. It is simply an administrative act of the Clerk which can be and will be vacated upon the showing of good. cause by any party.[4]

The procedure for responding to a conditional transfer order is set forth in the Panel Rules. First, a party served with the conditional transfer order should, within 7 days of its entry (not date of receipt), file a notice of opposition with the Clerk of the Panel.[5] The notice of opposition should be served on all parties. The notice of opposition need not be elegant or contain the reasons for opposing the conditional transfer order. Its purpose is to let the Clerk know that the conditional transfer order will be opposed and to prevent its being forwarded to the transferee court and transferor court for implementation.

Within 14 days after filing a notice of opposition, the party must file a motion to vacate the conditional transfer order and a brief in support of the motion.[6] This motion and brief should conform to the requirements of a motion for transfer.[7] If a party fails to file a motion to vacate and supporting brief after filing a notice of opposition, the Panel will deem the opposition withdrawn and the Clerk will forward the conditional transfer order to the transferee court.[8]

A party seeking to have the conditional order become final may file a reply brief. When the briefing is closed, the Clerk places the matter on for hearing in the same manner as any other motion before the Panel.[9]

An alternative procedure used by the Panel for transferring tag-along actions is to enter an order to show cause why transfer should not be ordered.[10] This procedure is used when the Panel has “reasonable anticipation of opposition to transfer.” The show-cause procedures in this situation are substantially the same as when the Panel initiates transfer by entry of an order to show cause, although the time limits are different. Any party may file an opposition to the order within 14 days, and the other parties may file a reply within seven additional days.[11]
